loans.name: Magda Elizabeth

texts.es:
La señora Magda Elizabeth B. es maestra de educación superior en la universidad UPONIC Esteli.
Magda va usar este crédito para pago de mano de obra por la construcción de un cuarto.
Ella espera que con el pago de la mano de obra pueda construir su cuarto ya que lo esta necesitando y así condicionar su casa.
Magda es casada y no tiene hijo. Este es su segundo crédito con Ceprodel y tiene dos años de estar trabajando con Ceprodel ella dijo que los créditos le han ayudado mucho a mejorar su casa.
texts.en:
Magda teaches at UPONIC Esteli University. She will use the money from this loan to pay for labor needed to build an extra room that she needs in her home. She is married but has no children. This will be her second loan through CEPRODEL and has been working with CEPRODEL for two years. She said that the loans have been a great help toward improving her home.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Labor for construction

loans.name: Comercita

texts.en:
Comercita D. is from the village of San Roque, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 40 years old. Comercita is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Comercita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Comercita has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Comercita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Comercita is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to support the education of her children.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Merlie

texts.en:
Merlie is 44 years old and married, with four children. She lives in the province of Antique with her husband, who works long hours as a fisherman to support the family. To supply additional income for her family, Merlie would like to tak out a new loan of 48,000 PHP to expand the family fish vending business. With the loan, Merlie plans to purchase additional fishing equipment and a pump boat (an outrigger canoe with a small engine) which will increase their harvest and income potential.

A dedicated member of ASHI for fourteen years, Merlie is grateful for access to capital to support her entrepreneurial dreams. Merlie is a member of the first ASHI center that opened in the San Jose branch of the Antique province in the Philippines. She has achieved strong performance with regular attendance to group meetings and timely loan repayments. With the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders, Merlie hopes the family venture will continue to flourish to improve the long term financial stability of her family.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment and a motor fishing boat.

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes T. is from the village of Capihan, Tacangon, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 36 years old. Lourdes is widowed and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Lourdes owns and operates a specialized retail business. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling firewood in the local community. Lourdes has been engaged in this business for over four years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Lourdes joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lourdes is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to support the education of her children.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Pinky

texts.en:
Pinky is 36 years old and married with three children. She is also expecting another child shortly. Her husband works as a tricycle driver in the province of Antique. To support the needs of her growing family, Pinky is requesting a loan of 20,000 Philippine pesos to invest in her hog-breeding business. With the loan, Pinky plans on purchasing an additional boar and raw materials to expand the pig pen.

A dedicated member of ASHI since 2003, Pinky is grateful for access to capital to support her entrepreneurial dreams. She has achieved strong performance with regular attendance to group meetings and timely loan repayments. With the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders, Pinky is hopeful that her hog-breeding venture will continue to flourish to fund the college education of her three children and the financial needs of her expanding family.

loans.use: To purchase pigs for breeding

loans.name: Marissa's Group

texts.en:
Marissa B. is from the village of Sonquil, Sta. Barbara, Pangasinan. She is 35 years old and is the group leader of an 8-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Marissa B. Group.

Marissa is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Marissa owns and operates a business venture in the food sector, operating a butcher shop in the market. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from butchering and selling a variety of meats in the market. Marissa has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Marissa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marissa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Marissa is now requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Marissa from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Ryan

texts.en:
Ryan S. is from the village of Cantaan, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 22 years old. Ryan is single. To make a living, Ryan owns & operates a service-based business providing transport services to local community members. Ryan has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Ryan joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Ryan is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide better service. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Ryan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide better service.

loans.name: Marling

texts.es:
La señora Marling I. es maestra de educación de primaria.
Marling va usar este crédito para pagar un curso de estudio universitario de su hijo para optar al titulo de profesionalización. Ella espera que con el crédito su hijo pueda pagar los gasto del curso y por ende obtener el titulo.
Marling es casada y tiene dos hijos ambos en edad escolar. Este es su segundo crédito con Ceprodel y tiene dos años de trabajar con crédito con Ceprodel ella expresa que los crédito le han ayudado mucho por que ha podido ayudar a su hijo en los estudios.
texts.en:
Marling I. is a primary school teacher. She will use this loan to pay for a university course of study for her son, who is working toward his professional certification. Marling is married and has two school-aged children. This is her second loan with Ceprodel. She has been working with Ceprodel for two years, and says that the loans they have provided have helped her greatly. They have helped her son advance in his studies.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pay for a university course for professional certification

loans.name: Yolanda

Yolanda C. is from the village of Catohugan, Mahinog Camiguin Province. She is 41 years old. Yolanda is married and has 2 school-aged children. loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn M. is from the village of Ramon Magsaysay, Sindangan,Zamboanga del Norte. She is 42 years old, married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Jocelyn owns and manages a Jeepney transport in town. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for 3 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month for these activities.

At present, Jocelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials for car repair. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Jocelyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: Car Repair

location.town: Ramon Magsaysay, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Mok

texts.en: Mrs. S. has been in the farming business for years. She plants various crops and raises a few pigs to earn a living. She typically generates an income of $5 per day. Mrs. S. is a widowed mother caring for three teenage children. All three of her children are students in the local public school. Mrs. S. has requested a loan of $1200 to be used to purchase a cultivating machine. With a new machine she can both plow her own farmland or rent it out to other farmers for additional profit.

loans.use: To purchase a cultivating machine.

loans.name: Rubilyn Abu-Abu Group

texts.en:
Rubilyn A. is from the village of Colupan Alto, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 31 years old. Rubilyn is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Rubilyn A. Group.

In 2007, Rubilyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rubilyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Rubilyn is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 6th loan from PMPC. loans.name: Jose Aurelio

texts.es:
El señor Jose es trabajor de la empresa ENACAL desempeñándose como operador de la maquina en la pila séptica.
Jose va usar el crédito para la compra de cerdo para destace ya que el trabaja de lunes a viernes y los fines de semana se dedica al comercio de carne de cerdo.
El espera que con la compra de cerdo para destace pueda obtener otros ingreso. Jose es acompañado y tiene un hijo .Este es el primer crédito con Ceprodel.
texts.en:
Jose is a worker for a business calles ENACAL. He is a machine operator for the septic system. Jose is going to use the loan to purchase a pig to butcher. He works Monday through Friday and on weekends works in the pork business. He hopes that with the purchase of the pig to butcher he will be able to get more income. Jose has a partner and he has a son. This is the first loan that he has had with Ceprodel.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a pig to butcher

loans.name: Kulshanbu Kanaeva`s Group

texts.ru:
Сарвар, 52, замужем. У нее 4 детей: 2  сына и 2 дочери. Старшие двое детей находятся на заработках в России. С родителями проживает только младший сын. Клиент и ее супруг занимаются разведением МРС, преимущественно коз. Кроме этого на своем участке они выращивают яблоки. В данное время у нее есть 10 коз и корова с теленком. Кредит будет использован для закупа 2 коз другой породы. 

Мехман, 53, замужем. Мать 5 детей. Самой младшей дочери 22 года. Супруг клиента помогает ей в бизнесе. Клиент закупает МРС на рынке, откармливает около 30 дней и перепродает с прибылью. У них есть 15 коз, корова и один теленок. Кредит будет использован для закупа 10 овец.

Кулшанбу является лидером этой группы. Она замужем и проживает со своей семьей в Кадамже. У нее 3 детей: 1 сын и две дочери. Клиент занимается торговлей продуктами питания с магазина который находится около ее дома. Кредит запрашивается для увеличения ассортимента товаров в магазине.

Гульнур 56 лет, вдова. У нее трое взрослых детей. Клиент работает поваром в столовой местной администрации, а также привозит с соседнего Узбекистана хлеб для реализации в своей столовой.  Кроме этого в своем доме она печет булочки и пирожки. Кредит нужен для закупа 2 мешков муки.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Kulshanbu is the leader of this group. She’s married and lives with her family in Kadamje. She has three children: one son and two daughters. She sells food products from a store, which is close to her home. She is asking for a loan in order to increase the variety of products in the store. Sarver, 52, is married. She has four children: two sons and two daughters. Her two eldest children work in Russia. Only her youngest son lives with her. Sarvar and her husband breed large and small cattle, mainly sheep. Additionally, they grow apples in their yard. Up to this day, they own ten sheep, a cow and her calf. The loan they receive will be used to buy two more sheep of a different breed. Mehman is fifty-three years old and a mother of five children. Her youngest daughter is twenty-two years old. Mehman is together in this business with her husband. They buy small or large cattle on the market, fatten it for about thirty days and resell it for profit. They have fifteen sheep, a cow and a calf. Their loan will be used to attain ten new sheep. Gulnur, 56, is a widow. She has three grown-up children. She works as a chef in the local administrative building. Additionally, she imports bread from adjacent Uzbekistan to sell in her kitchen. She also bakes pastries and rolls.

Translated from Russian by Alex Kostrubsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 2 goats

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina L. is from the village of Magting, Mambajao Camiguin Province. She is 36 years old. Regina is separated from her spouse and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Regina owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) store, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Regina has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately $75 a month from this activity.

In 2010, Regina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Regina is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children.

loans.name: Em

texts.en:
Mrs. M. is an internal staff member in a ministry located in the middle of Phnom Penh, and she gets a suitable salary. By doing her job, she is able to cover all the needs of her family. She now has four children. One of them is married and the others are single and work in a garment factory. 

M. has a life partner in her husband, who appears in the picture above. He sells merchandise to students who learn different skills in Korean schools. M. wants a loan for her husband to use as capital in order to improve his trade. This action will provide the family with extra income and improve their standard of life.

loans.use: To improve his merchandise trade.

loans.name: Fatima's Group

texts.en:
Fatima A. is from the village of Manano, Mallig, Isabela. She is 37 years old and is the group leader of a 9-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Fatima A.'s Group.

Fatima is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Fatima owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and for sale. Fatima has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Fatima joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fatima has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. Fatima has now requested a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Fatima from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Tserendolgor

texts.en:
Tserendolgor is 38 years old and lives with her husband and two children in the Baganuur district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in an apartment which they own. Her son and daughter both attend a local secondary school. 

Tserendolgor operates a second-hand product trading business in her area. She sells a variety of second-hand clothes and blankets. During the summer months, she uses her truck to travel to the surrounding countryside to sell her products. Tserendolgor started selling second-hand goods in 2006 and has steadily grown her business over the years. She is an honest person and has a great communication skills. 

She has many goals for the future and says, “I would like to renovate my summer house into a winter house before my two children become university students. For this reason, I must increase my working capital and profit.” Tserendolgor is requesting a 700,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase a variety of second-hand clothes to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more second-hand clothes

loans.name: Chann

texts.en:
Mr. Chann Y is a 55-year-old farmer who lives in a commune in Siem Reap Province. Chann Y is married to Roov, age 42. This couple, who work together in the farming business, has given birth to four children. 

Since 1995, Chann has always used a cow that he hired from his neighbor. Now he wants to reduce this expense by looking for assistance in buying his own cow. He is happy that this loan will provide him with a new asset and he intends to raise the cow for breeding in the future. 

(Mr. Chann Y was not available at the time, so his wife and his son are pictured instead.)

loans.use: To buy a cow.

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Willy

texts.en:
Willy J., 52, is making sure that he provides enough for his family's daily needs. Married to Gemma J., they are blessed with one child. He makes sure that he provides well so that their family can have a better life.  He has been buying and selling a variety of products.

Willy has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than two years now. He regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays his weekly dues consistently. Because of his good repayment performance with his previous loans, he has been able to borrow seven times in CCT’s Cooperative.  He is consistent in paying his dues because he uses the money he borrowed to expand and improve his business.

Now with your help, he would like to apply for a 15,000 PHP loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for buying equipment and products needed to continue the operations of his business.

He dreams that his business will continue to grow so that he can have a good and comfortable life with his family.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro-Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy equipment and products needed to continue the operations of his business.

loans.name: Francisco Javier

texts.es:
Francisco Javier Z. es trabajador de la universidad UNAN Esteli en el área de seguridad.
Francisco va usar el crédito para pago de mano de la mejora de vivienda.
Francisco espera que con el crédito pueda pagar la mano de obra de la construcción de su casa y así darle una mejor condición.
Francisco es casado el cual tiene dos hijos . Este es su segundo crédito con Ceprodel y tiene dos años de trabajar con Ceprodel.
El expresa que los créditos otorgados por Ceprodel le han ayudado mucho.
texts.en:
Francisco Javier Z. works in security for the UNAN university. Francisco is going to use the loan to pay for the labor to improve his housing. Francisco hopes that with the loan he can pay the labor costs for the construction of his house and better its condition. Francisco is married and has two children. This is his second loan with Ceprodel and he has been working with Ceprodel for two years. He says that the loans granted through Ceprodel have helped him a lot.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To pay for the labor costs to improve his housing.

loans.name: Orlom

texts.en:
Orlom is 37 years old and lives with her husband and five children in Hovd province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. All of her children, three sons and two daughters, attend a local secondary school. They have been living in their current home for five years.

Orlom operates a clothing trading business out of a shipping container at the local market in her town. She sells a variety of men's and women's clothing items to her many customers. She has been operating her business since 2003 and has steadily grown her business.

Orlom is a very open-minded person and has good business sense. Last October she used her earnings to purchase another container at a different location in the town to expand her business. Orlom's business is very important for her and she says, “It seemed that people who have two containers make more profit. Therefore, I purchased a new container for my business. Now it is important for me to purchase more inventory.”

Orlam hopes to continue to grow her business in the future and is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase a variety of new inventory for her clothing trading business.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of new inventory

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
40-year-old Gina B. is a new member of Kiva’s first field partner in the Philippines - ASHI. She is a domestic helper of someone in their village and it is her way to earn money.

The salary she is receiving from her employer monthly is just too small to support the growing needs of her family, especially her three children. Soon she will have to spend a lot because her eldest, 13-year-old, child will be in college. Her other two children are eight years old and one year old.

Gina really wants her children to graduate from college and have a different way of living. They must not be as poor as they are at present. Since her husband is unemployed, her aspiration would seem to be impossible. Therefore she wanted to have her own business using the loan she is presently requesting from Kiva.

Gina is planning to start a small business selling clothes. She plans for her items to be sold directly to people and she is optimistic that they would be salable because, compared to the ones sold in the market, the price of her goods would be much cheaper and her customers wouldn’t have to pay their fare to go to the market.

Gina really hopes that someday her business will grow to be more profitable and her life would be different.

loans.use: To purchase ready-to-wear clothes to sell

loans.name: Esterlita

texts.en: Esterlita C. is from the village of Tubod, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 49 years old, is married, and has five adult children. Esterlita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Esterlita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. Esterlita plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina G., 40, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. Married to Ador G., an employee, she makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own sidewalk stall for quite some time now.

Gina has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow eleven times from CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her business.

Now, with your help, Gina would like to obtain a PHP 15,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying groceries and expanding her business.

Gina dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can finally have her own grocery store.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more groceries and expand her business

loans.name: Arnie

texts.en: Mrs. Arnie P. is from the village of Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 21 years old, married, and blessed with one child. Her primary source of income is from her business, a "sari-sari" store (small grocery), with a monthly net income of 2,500 PHP. Arnie has been a member of Paglaum Multipurpose Cooperative since 2009, and she is now on her 3rd loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used as additional capital for her sari-sari store. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Nyakaina Central Development Group, Rukungiri

texts.en:
M. Enos at the top left of the group photo also appears in the small photo and he is a 79-year-old married man, residing in Nyakana village, Rukungiri. He is a married man with three children, all going to school.

Enos is a cattle farmer involved in the sale of milk and cites the inflated prices of drugs and other veterinary essentials as one of his drawbacks. He has been operating his business for a period of over twenty-five years and he reckons that he makes profits amounting to 35,000/= per week.

Enos is a devoted and hardworking gentleman whose friendly line of conduct has endeared him to many customers. He anticipates his livelihood will be improved once he obtains this loan to buy more drugs and pay his workers.

loans.use: To buy more drugs and pay his workers

loans.name: Celia

texts.en: Celia B. is from the village of Binaliwan, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 51 years old, is married, and has five adult children. Celia owns and operates a specialized retail business selling "RTW" or ready-to-wear clothes in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twelve years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month. In 2010, Celia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. Celia plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rwakirungura People's Association, Rukungiri Group

texts.en:
K. Kenneth at the top right of the group photo also appears in the group photo and he is a 48-year-old married man and a banana plantation farmer in Nyabicence, Buyanja Sub County in Rukungiri district. He is a father to five children, plus one orphan who are all pursuing education.

Kenneth has been in the banana plantation business for the last eighteen years and attributes his longevity in the business to his good human relationship skills. He calculates that his business generates cash to the tune of 40,000 UGX per week and his business objective from the onset has always been to modernize his banana plantation so as to get more substantial value from it.

By his own account, one of the major challenges he has to grapple with is the unpredictable and adverse weather conditions which constantly destroy crops in that part of the country.

Kenneth hopes to educate all his children up to university level once he is able to elevate his business venture in the course of time. He envisages he will be able to buy more manure, pay his laborers on time and buy more farm equipment with this loan.

loans.use: To buy manure, pay his laborers, and buy more farm equipment

loans.name: Amalia

texts.en:
Amalia is married with six children and lives with her husband, a painter, in the province of Antique. Blessed with a large family, Amalia strives hard to support the financial needs of her children.

As a busy entrepreneur, Amalia manages her own business weaving native bags and hats. She is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP to sustain her business and purchase additional materials. Amalia thoroughly enjoys the creativity involved in designing and producing her native handicrafts and has built a loyal base of customers in her neighborhood.

A dedicated member of ASHI since 2007, Amalia has been a model member demonstrating regular attendance at weekly meetings and timely repayments on loans.  Since joining ASHI, she has gained more self-confidence as a businesswoman and entrepreneur managing her own venture.

Amalia’s future ambitions are to sustain the profitability of her business and fund the education of her children.

loans.use: To purchase more raw materials for her business

loans.name: Rhoda

texts.en: Rhoda B. is from the village of Poblacion, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 54 years old and is married. Rhoda owns and operates a specialized retail business, selling a variety of goods like thread, blades, knives and other items in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twelve years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Rhoda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. Rhoda plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family’s income. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Atesh 1 Group

texts.en:
Edres is the group leader of Atesh 1 Group. He lives in the 11th district of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is single and lives in a household of six members. Even though he is single, he feels lots of responsibilities towards his family members.

Edres has a restaurant and he has been involved in this business more than six years. He has lots of clients there who like to come to his hotel (restaurant) for the delicious food which is cooked there.

Edres needs the loan to expand his business and purchase more necessary things like new chairs and tables for his hotel to attract more clients. He hopes to grow his business and to support his younger brothers and sisters, enabling them to receive a better education.

loans.use: To expand his restaurant and buy new tables and chairs

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn G. is from the village of Magting, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 37 years old, is widowed, and has four school-aged children. Evelyn owns and operates a food stall, selling specialty food products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Evelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. Evelyn plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family’s income. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nyakabungo Tukwatanise Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
T. Mariah, at the top right also appears in the group photo and she is a 43-year-old married woman, is a teacher with five children of her own and one dependent.

Mariah has been  a teacher at Ibanda Bright School for twenty years and earns one hundred thousand shillings a month while teaching. She attributes her long track record to her trustworthy nature.

On the face of it, Mariah seems reserved but actually is very friendly and she says that she needs this loan to be able to pay her children’s school fees.

Mariah intends to go for an upgrade course in education, at one of Uganda’s leading universities in the near future. She, in the event that this should come to pass, envisions a bright future for her family and herself.

loans.use: To pay her children's school fees

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn G., 55, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. She is married to Angelito G., a violin maker, and they are blessed with a child. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own string-instrument shop for the last sixteen years.

Evelyn has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than two years now. She regularly attends its weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow thirteen times from CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her instrument-making business.

Now, with your help, Evelyn would like to obtain a PHP 26,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying equipment and raw materials needed to continue production of their violins and guitars.

Evelyn dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can continue to provide for her child’s education. She also wants to continue helping other people like herself.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy equipment and raw materials needed to continue production of their violins and guitars

loans.name: Davlatali

texts.ru: Даминов Давлатали проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст, 49 лет. Женат, имеет 9 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сын на заработках в России. Сам Давлатали занимается растениеводством. У него земельный участок, где он сажает пшеницу и оващи. Урожай который он получает вывозит на рынок а часть оставляет своей семье. В этой области более 8 лет. В свободное время он предотавляет услугу, такси. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений. Давлатали хочет получить хороший урожай, что привлечет новых клиентов.
texts.en:
Davlatali D. lives in the Hamadoni district. He is 49 years old, married and has 9 children. His wife is a homemaker. His son works in Russia. Davlatali is involved in agriculture. He has a plot of land, where he grows wheat and vegetables. He sells part of the received harvest at the market and leaves some for his family. He has been in this business for over 8 years. Davlatali also provides taxi service in his spare time. He is requesting the loan for the purchase of mineral fertilizers. Davlatali wants to get a good harvest, which will attract new customers.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of mineral fertilizers

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Bubare Bakyara Tukwatanise Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
For the last thirty years, 52-year-old N. Kiviri Valeria, has been selling goats and doing mobile catering in Jubilee to support her family. The friendly mother of five reveals that she can make up to 180,000 UGX a week and her monthly estimates are even higher.

By her own account, what makes Kiviri’s business drive that winning edge is the fact that she values that virtue called customer care.

Kiviri wants to see to it that all her children are well educated and she says a loan will be her trump card in achieving this. She needs a loan to be able to buy more goats to sell. She is a very friendly, cooperative and hardworking lady.

N. Kiviiri Valeria appears at the top left in the small photo just like in the big group photo as their leader.

loans.use: To buy more goats to sell

loans.name: Janice

texts.en:
Janice M., 27, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. She is married to Joel M., an appraiser, and they are blessed with a child. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own variety store for quite some time now.

Janice has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends its weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow four times from CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her variety store.

Now, with your help, Janice would like to obtain a PHP 10,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying groceries needed to replenish the current stocks in her product inventory.

Janice dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy groceries needed to replenish her current stock

loans.name: Rwengiri Modern Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
B. Agnes appears at the top left in the small photo just like in the group photo as the group leader.

It’s rare to come by female farmers in Uganda, but here is an exception. At the age of 38, B. Agnes is defying this stereotype and she has been a farmer from Kafunda in Ibanda for two years.

Agnes’s future prospects do not seem to be bad due to her hard work and friendliness. She will be able to expand her business and elevate her family’s standard of living, once she can access a loan to be able to pay her workers and buy manure and mulch her farm.

Agnes is grateful for her loans since she has benefitted a lot and makes more profits from the increased investments.

loans.use: To pay laborers, buy manure and mulch her farm.

loans.name: Holmahmad

texts.ru: Абдулназаров Холмахмад проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст, 53 года. Женат, имеет 15 детей. Двое сыновей занимаются торговлей в городе Душанбе. Сам Холмахмад имеет средне- специальное образование "Механизатор". По профессии работал 18 лет. Сейчас он занимается растениеводством. Имеет земельный участок, где сажает пшеницу и другие злаковые культуры. В этой области более 8 лет. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений. Холмахмад хочет посеить и получить хороший урожай для продажи.
texts.en:
Holmahmad A. lives in the Hamadoni district. He is 53 years old, married and has 15 children. Two of his sons are involved in retail sales in the city of Dushanbe. Holmahmad has a secondary-specialized education as a mechanic. He spent 18 years working in that field. Now he is involved in agriculture. He has a plot of land, where he grows wheat and other grains. Holmahmad has been in this business for over 8 years. He is requesting the loan for the purchase of mineral fertilizers. Holmahmad wants to plant and get a good harvest for sale.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of mineral fertilizers

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Engari Nyekundire Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
L. Ziporah is the leader of her lending group in Ibanda. She has been a medical worker and birth attendant in Ibanda for over thirty years.

Ziporah is grateful for her loans for they have helped her expand her business as well as enabled her pay her children’s school fees. She is a good lady who knows how to handle her clients, and this has won her many genuine friends. She is able to make 350,000/= in profit a month.

Ziporah is a 52-year-old lady and is married with six children, all in primary school. She also takes care of three dependents. Her major goal is to improve her business by providing quality services and to ensure that her family is happy and healthy.

Ziporah needs a loan to help expand her business by buying more supplies for medical care.

loans.use: To buy more medicines and drugs

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou S., 41, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. She is married to Felino S., a vendor, and they are blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been selling electronic accessories for quite some time now.

Marilou has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends its weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow eight times from CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her business.

Now, with your help, Marilou would like to obtain a PHP 12,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying additional electronic products that she can sell.

Marilou dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy additional electronic products to sell

loans.name: Floria's Group

texts.en:
Floria B. is from the village of Manano. She is 58 years old. Floria is the group leader of a 10-member group. While each member of the group receives an individual loan through ASKI, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is the Floria B. Group.

Floria is married and has two adult children. To earn a living, Floria owns and operates a general store. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Floria has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Floria joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. Floria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Floria is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This  will be the eleventh loan taken out by Floria through ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue it generates to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva and edited by a human editor. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new products to expand selection

loans.name: Isabel

texts.en:
Isabel B., 58, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. She is married to Fernando B., a retiree, and they are blessed with four children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own variety store for the last eighteen years.

Isabel has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends its weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow sixteen times from CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her variety store.

Now, with your help, Isabel would like to obtain a PHP 15,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying groceries and other supplies needed to replenish her current product inventory.

Isabel dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she is able to show her children, through her example, how to be self-reliant and independent.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy groceries and other supplies needed to replenish her inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional products

loans.name: Li-An's Group

texts.en:
Li-an D. is from the village of Manano. She is 34 years old. Li-an is the group leader of a 10-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Li-an Diampo's Group.

Li-an is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Li-an owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Li-an has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Li-an joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Li-an has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

Lewulo F. is currently in the business of selling bread and tea at her restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more milk packets. Forty-years-old and widowed, Lewulo has seven children, none of whom go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a big hotel.

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith C., 39, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Joseph C., a taxi driver, they are blessed with seven children. Edith makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life, managing her own variety store for seven years now.

Edith has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now, regularly attending their weekly fellowship meetings and consistently paying her weekly dues . Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times from CCT’s Cooperative, using the money to expand and improve her variety store. Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 27,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital in her expanding business to buy groceries to replenish her current product inventory and continue operations of her variety store.

Edith dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide a comfortable home for her children. She also works hard for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: To buy groceries to replenish her current product inventory and continue operations of her variety store.

loans.name: Rosenette

texts.en:
Rosenette is 47-years-old, married with two children, and lives in the province of Antique with her husband. To supply additional income for her family, Rosenette manages her own business selling sweet delicacies to a loyal customer base in the community. Her specialty is “bukayo”, a dessert made from young coconut and sugar topped with sesame seeds. She is requesting a loan of 25,000 PHP to expand her entrepreneurial venture as she truly enjoys making little indulgent treats for her patrons to enjoy. These treats are especially popular gifts and souvenirs for visiting Filipinos who now live abroad.

Rosenette has been a dedicated member of ASHI since 2006, demonstrating regular attendance at weekly meetings and steady repayments on previous loans. Her long-term goals are to expand her business, grow brand recognition of her venture “Rosenette’s Sweet Bukayo” throughout the province, and build savings to fund her children’s education.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for her sweet delicacy production and to increase the volume of her production.

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en:
Luisa R., 39, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Ricardo R., a driver, they are blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn money so that their family can have a better life.  She has been juggling three businesses in the past five years. She does direct selling for the country’s popular cosmetics and clothing brands, she has her own electronic cellular phone loading station, and a buy-and-sell business.

Luisa has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.     

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a 26,000 Philippine peso loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying more products to be incorporated into her inventory.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education. She also envisions herself having her own house.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: Store inventory

loans.name: Bebe Awa Anisa Group

texts.en:
Anisa is a member of Bebe Awa Anisa group. She lives in the 11th district of Kabul, Afghanistan, and is married with four children.

She is a tailor and has been involved in this business for more than six years. She is a very hardworking woman and sews all kinds of clothes, small and big sizes. She is happy that she can support her family members in a good way. 

She needs the loan to purchase cloth and different kinds of threads. She hopes to expand her business in the near future and have a shop instead of working in the house.

Rosalie is widowed and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Rosalie owns & operates a manufacturing business. She manufactures & sells clay products to local businesses and community members. Rosalie has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Rosalie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Rosalie is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Rosalie from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family.

Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Ngan thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 20 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Ngan kiếm được khoảng 500.000 VND. Vào 2003, Ngan đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Tham (9) là 33 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4,000,000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 5. L. T. Tham (10) là 28 tuổi nữ. Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa. *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina O., 58, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Leonisio O., a retiree who is receiving pension, they are blessed with six children, five of whom are already married. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own variety store for quite some time now.

Josefina has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her variety store.     

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 12,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying groceries needed to replenish stocks and continue operation of her variety store.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow and be successful.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy groceries needed to replenish stocks and continue operation of her variety store.

Nadija is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Nadija owns & operates a " carenderia"  business venture in the food sector (a restaurant). While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from serving local foods to customers in the local community. Nadija has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for this activity. 

In 2000, Nadija joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nadija has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Nadija is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita Y., 58, is making sure that her family has enough to provide for their daily needs. Her husband, Romeo Y., is a welder and tricycle driver (a motor bike with a passenger car), and they are blessed with four children. Rosita helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She is a tricycle operator who also sells cosmetics and cell phone credits. 

Rosita has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her businesses.     

Now she is applying for a PHP 14,000 loan. This loan will be used to add capital to her business by buying cosmetics for her direct selling line. She will also invest some of the loan to buy phone credits for various networks and a small portion will be spent on buying fuel for the tricycle.

She dreams that her businesses will continue to grow. She also wants her children to have comfortably settled and happy lives.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: Primarily buying cosmetics to sell.  Also, cell phone credits to sell and fuel for her tricycle.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. texts.en:
Gloria C., 45, is making sure that her family has enough provision for their daily needs. Married to Alfredo C., an overseas Filipino worker, she is blessed with three children. Now with your help, she would like to apply for a loan of 14,000 PHP. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying groceries needed to replenish stocks and continue the operation of her general store. Gloria dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education and give them a bright future.

loans.name: Dilbarhon Melibaeva`s Group

texts.ru:
Дилбархон 47 лет. Она вдова. У нее двое детей: сын и дочь. Сын находится на заработках в России, а дочь проживает вместе с мужем. Дилбархон активно занимается розничной торговлей товаров повседневного спроса с маленького ларька около дома. Этим бизнесом она начала заниматься два года тому назад. Кредит запрашивается для закупа новой продукции для ларька.Это позволит ей увеличить доход, т.к. это единственный такого рода ларек в округе. 

Мадинахон 26 лет. Она проживает вместе с родителями и братьями. Вся семья занимается полеводством. В данное очень много времени уделяют подготовке к весенное посевной. В этом году они собираются посеять картофель. Кредит будет использован для закупа семян. 

Хуртожихон, 51, вдова. Ее сын находится на заработках в России. Она занимается разведением и откормом домашнего скота. Кредит запрашивается для покупки дойной коровы, что позволит ей производить молоко и молочные продукты. 

Нигора, 39. У нее трое детей: старшая дочь работает поваром, остальные двое школьники. Супруг работает таксистом. Она сама занимается реализацией овощей и круп на рынке Аравана. В основном она реализует лук, картофель, жмых. Кредит запрашивается для увеличения товарного запаса овощей. 

Учкунбеку 22 года. Он проживает вместе с родителями и младшим братом. Сам клиент занимается птицеводством и пчеловодством. В бизнесе участвуют практически все члены семьи. Кредит будет использован для закупа 1 коровы. 


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Dilbarhon is 47 years old. She is a widow and has two children: a son and a daughter. Her son works in Russia, and the daughter lives with her husband. Dilbarhon is actively involved in retail sales of everyday-use goods at a small retail store near her home. She started this business two years ago. She is requesting the loan for the purchase of new merchandise for the store. This will help Dilbarhon increase her income because this is the only store of this type in the area. Madinahon is 26 years old. She lives together with her parents and brothers. The whole family is involved in farming. They currently spend a lot of time preparing for the spring sowing. This year, they plan to plant potatoes. The loan will be used for the purchase of seeds. Hurtojihon is 51 years old. She is a widow. Her son is in Russia for work. She is involved in breeding and feeding domestic livestock. Hurtojihon is requesting the loan for the purchase of a dairy cow, which will allow her to produce milk and dairy products. Nigora is 39 years old. She has three children. The oldest daughter works as a cook, and the other two go to school. Nigora’s husband works as a taxi driver. She is involved in sales of vegetables and grains at the Aravan market. She primarily sells onions, potatoes and pomace. Nigora is requesting the loan in order to increase the stock of vegetables. Uchkunbek is 22 years old. He lives together with his parents and younger brother. He is involved in bird husbandry and beekeeping. The whole family participates in this business. The loan will be used for the purchase of 1 cow.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of new merchandise

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta A., 39, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Nolito A., a laborer, and they are blessed with two children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been doing direct selling of popular brands of clothing and cosmetics for quite some time now.

Julieta has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her business.     

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a 12,000 Philippines peso loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by allowing her to buy advance orders in her direct-selling business.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education. She also envisions a comfortably well-off future for herself and her children.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buying advance orders for her direct selling business.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth has a bar and restaurant where she sells drinks and Nigerian cooked foods. Her customers love her cooked foods and she has high patronage. She loves her business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. 

Ruth is married with six children and she is 40 years old. Her husband is a civil servant and he also supports their home. She has been in this business for two years. She hopes to grow her business. She is requesting a loan of 30,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Cristeta's Group

texts.en:
Cristeta D. C. is from the village of Holy Friday. She is 55 years old. Cristeta is the group leader of an 11-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Cristeta D. C.'s Group.

Cristeta is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Cristeta owns & operates an agricultural business raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. Cristeta has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Cristeta joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cristeta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. Cristeta is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Cristeta from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it.

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.
